newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: CZECH MINISTERS AGREE DISTRICT HEAT DEREGULATION.
newsitem.headline: CZECH MINISTERS AGREE DISTRICT HEAT DEREGULATION.

text.p: The Czech Council of Economic Ministers on Monday agreed to deregulate the price of district heating, Labour and Social Affairs Minister Jindrich Vodicka said.
Following a meeting of the council Vodicka told reporters the ministers agreed to switch "from regulated prices to prices adopted according to inflation and other normal indicators."
He said the ministers also agreed that there should be some type of social compensation to soften the impact of the decision on those unable to pay.
District heating plants account for most of the heat provided to the large Communist-era housing estates where many Czechs live, and are heavily subsidised by the state.
The issue of deregualtion of utilities prices has been one of the most sensitive in the Czech post-Communist reforms.
Vodicka said this all must be first approved by the full cabinet before the final budget plan for 1997 is approved. That is expected within the next two weeks.
The full cabinet, which rarely rejects decisions of the economic ministers, has its next regular meeting on Wednesday.
